poem:
"A Soul's Refrain"

Beneath Memphis lights,
Resonates hope, in wax grooves spun.
Stax birthed stars from night,
In glory, mid-sixties sun.

Booker T, Redding rose,
Beats pulsing, tunes humming free.
A beacon against woes,
In soul's stately symphony.

Yet fortunes wavered, dipped,
Year gone, label teetered brink.
Echoes of hits, softly whipped,
Music, like faith, doesn't sink.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It became a beacon of hope’: the incredible story of Stax Records During its breakout phase in the mid-1960s, Stax Records seemed to be soaring. The small company from Memphis managed to score huge, international hits with the new stars it introduced, like Booker T & the MGs (Green Onions), Otis Redding (I’ve Been Loving You Too Long), and Sam & Dave (Hold On, I’m Coming). Just one year later, however, the label teetered on". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
